body:
Hi @peastman,

I just tested the following code:

```python
import torch
import torchani
print(torch.__version__)
print(torchani.__version__)

model = torchani.models.ANI1ccx()
module = torch.jit.script(model[0])
print(module.graph)

class ANIForce(torch.nn.Module):

    def __init__(self, model, species):
        super(ANIForce, self).__init__()
        self.model = model
        self.species = species

    def forward(self, positions):
        _, energy = self.model((self.species, 10.0*positions.unsqueeze(0)))
        return 2625.5000885335317*energy

force = ANIForce(model[0], torch.zeros(1, 5))
module = torch.jit.script(force)
print(module.graph)
```

and seems to be working well with output:

```
1.5.0a0+0c91d4c
1.3.dev2+g987711c
graph(%self : __torch__.torchani.nn.Sequential,
      %input_.1 : (Tensor, Tensor),
      %cell.1 : Tensor?,
      %pbc.1 : Tensor?):
  %5 : __torch__.torchani.aev.AEVComputer = prim::GetAttr[name="0"](%self)
  %7 : __torch__.torchani.nn.ANIModel = prim::GetAttr[name="1"](%self)
  %9 : __torch__.torchani.utils.EnergyShifter = prim::GetAttr[name="2"](%self)
  %input_.3 : NamedTuple(species : Tensor, aevs : Tensor) = prim::CallMethod[name="forward"](%5, %input_.1, %cell.1, %pbc.1) # /home/xgao/torchani/torchani/nn.py:99:21
  %input_.5 : NamedTuple(species : Tensor, energies : Tensor) = prim::CallMethod[name="forward"](%7, %input_.3, %cell.1, %pbc.1) # /home/xgao/torchani/torchani/nn.py:99:21
  %input_.7 : NamedTuple(species : Tensor, energies : Tensor) = prim::CallMethod[name="forward"](%9, %input_.5, %cell.1, %pbc.1) # /home/xgao/torchani/torchani/nn.py:99:21
  return (%input_.7)

graph(%self : __torch__.ANIForce,
      %positions.1 : Tensor):
  %10 : None = prim::Constant()
  %4 : float = prim::Constant[value=10]() # test.py:18:46
  %6 : int = prim::Constant[value=0]() # test.py:18:71
  %15 : float = prim::Constant[value=2625.5]() # test.py:19:15
  %2 : __torch__.torchani.nn.Sequential = prim::GetAttr[name="model"](%self)
  %3 : Tensor = prim::GetAttr[name="species"](%self)
  %7 : Tensor = aten::unsqueeze(%positions.1, %6) # test.py:18:51
  %8 : Tensor = aten::mul(%7, %4) # <string>:3:9
  %9 : (Tensor, Tensor) = prim::TupleConstruct(%3, %8)
  %12 : NamedTuple(species : Tensor, energies : Tensor) = prim::CallMethod[name="forward"](%2, %9, %10, %10) # test.py:18:20
  %13 : Tensor, %energy.1 : Tensor = prim::TupleUnpack(%12)
  %17 : Tensor = aten::mul(%energy.1, %15) # <string>:3:9
  return (%17)
```

I think what you are seeing is a PyTorch bug which has already been fixed by the latest PyTorch. Could you try upgrading your PyTorch to the latest nightly build and see if the error is still there?
Yes, installing the latest PyTorch nightly fixed it.  I'm glad it was that simple.  Thanks!

Than again, maybe I spoke too soon.  I can now convert the model to TorchScript.  But when I try to load it in (using the latest nightly build of LibTorch) it fails with this error:

```
Unexpected right-hand found in assignment in class body. This is not yet supported.:
Serialized   File "code/__torch__/torchani/aev.py", line 13
  EtaA : Tensor
  Zeta : Tensor
  aev_length : Final[int] = 384
                            ~~~ <--- HERE
  sizes : Final[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int]] = (4, 16, 64, 32, 320)
  angular_sublength : Final[int] = 32
```

@peastman This sounds like another bug. Could you upload your saved module and a minimum piece of libtorch code to reproduce this? I don't have any experience with libtorch, so it's hard for me to reproduce it myself.

@peastman Great! Thanks for the help and I am able to reproduce it using a minimal script:

```python
import torch
from torch.jit import Final
print(torch.__version__)

class Model(torch.nn.Module):
    a: Final[int]

    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.a = 5

    def forward(self, x):
        return x

m = torch.jit.script(Model())
torch.jit.save(m, 'model.pt')
torch.jit.load('model.pt')
```
@peastman I will file a bug report to PyTorch
But to solve your problem, for now, you could remove all the `Final` in https://github.com/aiqm/torchani/blob/master/torchani/aev.py#L309 manually and it should be working.
Thanks!  I'll give that a try.

issue.title: [libtorch, jit] Unexpected right-hand found in assignment in class body. This is not yet supported.

labels.name: oncall: jit
labels.description: Add this issue/PR to JIT oncall triage queue

labels.name: triaged
labels.description: This issue has been looked at a team member, and triaged and prioritized into an appropriate module

repository.name: pytorch
repository.description: Tensors and Dynamic neural networks in Python with strong GPU acceleration

issue.body:
## 🐛 Bug

Originally found by @peastman at https://github.com/aiqm/torchani/issues/407 and thanks for @peastman's minimal C++ script.

Libtorch is unable to load jit module with `Final` fields while Python `torch.jit.load` can.

## To Reproduce

Python:

```python
import torch
from torch.jit import Final
print(torch.__version__)

class Model(torch.nn.Module):
    a: Final[int]

    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.a = 5

    def forward(self, x):
        return x

m = torch.jit.script(Model())
torch.jit.save(m, 'model.pt')
torch.jit.load('model.pt')
```

C++
```c++
#include <torch/script.h>

int main() {
    torch::jit::load("model.pt");
    return 0;
}
```

The python code runs successfully, but the C++ code fails with

```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'torch::jit::script::ErrorReport'
  what():  
Unexpected right-hand found in assignment in class body. This is not yet supported.:
Serialized   File "code/__torch__.py", line 4
  __parameters__ = []
  training : bool
  a : Final[int] = 5
                   ~ <--- HERE
  def forward(self: __torch__.Model,
    x: Tensor) -> Tensor:

Aborted (core dumped)
```

## Expected behavior

Both python and libtorch succeeds.


cc @suo

body:
Unfortunately, removing the `Final` annotations from aev.py isn't enough.  If I do that, I just get the same error from a different class that's internal to PyTorch:

```
Exception: 
Unexpected right-hand found in assignment in class body. This is not yet supported.:
Serialized   File "code/__torch__/torch/nn/modules/linear.py", line 6
  weight : Tensor
  bias : Tensor
  out_features : Final[int] = 160
                              ~~~ <--- HERE
  in_features : Final[int] = 384
  def forward(self: __torch__.torch.nn.modules.linear.Linear,
```

So it looks like it will require a fix to PyTorch.
@peastman OK, let's just waiting for what people say at https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/31960

This looks like it's probably a versioning issue on our (PyTorch) end, this code works fine for me on a libtorch built on PyTorch master but fails in nightly libtorch. You could try [building from source](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch#from-source) in the meantime while we get this fixed.
This should be fixed now (see pytorch/pytorch#31960), the nightly build is now up to date and fixes this bug in my local testing.
@peastman Nightly libtorch build has been fixed officially by PyTorch. Could you please give it a try?
It works great.  Thank you, you're awesome!
